alert.note: Alert for East Carteret (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Coastal Flood Watch issued April 07 at 6:02PM EDT until April 10 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City
info.description: ...BEACH HAZARDS STATEMENT IN EFFECT FROM SATURDAY MORNING THROUGH SATURDAY EVENING... ...COASTAL FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT FROM SATURDAY EVENING THROUGH MONDAY MORNING... * WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Watch, up to 2 to 4 feet of inundation above ground level possible in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways. For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous rip currents, large breaking waves expected, and strong longshore currents in the surf zone. * WHERE...Eastern Carteret County. * WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Watch, from Saturday evening through Monday morning. For the Beach Hazards Statement, from Saturday morning through Saturday evening. * IMPACTS...Up to 2 to 4 feet of inundation above ground level is possible in some areas near shorelines and tidal waterways resulting in an elevated threat of property damage. Flooding will extend inland from the waterfront threatening some homes and businesses. Numerous road closures and flooding of vehicles will be possible. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and back injuries. Strong longshore currents will create dangerous swimming conditions. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Prolonged northeast winds will bring the greatest impacts along soundside locations. Conditions will continue to deteriorate through Saturday with greatest impacts expected Saturday night and Sunday. Time of high total tides are approximate to the nearest hour. Beaufort Marine Lab NC MLLW Categories - Minor 5.0 ft, Moderate 5.5 ft, Major 6.5 ft MHHW Categories - Minor -0.8 ft, Moderate -0.3 ft, Major 0.7 ft Total Total Departure Day/Time Tide Tide from Norm Waves Flood ft MLLW ft MHHW ft ft Impact -------- --------- --------- --------- ------- -------- 07/10 PM 4.2 -1.6 0.8 1 None 08/10 AM 4.1 -1.7 1.5 1 None 08/11 PM 5.2 -0.6 1.7 1 Minor 09/11 AM 4.4 -1.4 1.9 1 None 09/11 PM 5.6 -0.2 2.1 1 Moderate 10/11 AM 4.0 -1.8 1.7 1 None &&
info.instruction: If travel is required, allow extra time as some roads may be closed. Do not drive around barricades or through water of unknown depth. Take the necessary actions to protect flood-prone property. Life-threatening rip currents. If caught in a rip current, remain calm. Swim in a direction following the shoreline. If tired, float or tread water until out of the rip current. If unable to escape, face the shore and call or wave for help. Shore break occurs when waves break directly on the beach. It is extremely important to protect your head and neck whenever you are in breaking waves by keeping your hands in front of you at all times. Strong longshore currents can sweep swimmers and surfers into rip currents, piers, jetties and other hazardous areas. In many cases, the longshore current is strong enough to prevent swimmers from being able to keep their feet on the bottom making it difficult to return to shore.
